content.description: Fists and grunting lead to a rightward hand traverse. Take the early exit up steep hand cracks or miss your exit to a finger crack ending. Belay on gear at the ledge, and scramble off right.
content.protection: A single rack, bring a #5 to make you feel all warm and fuzzy.
content.location: It is around right on the south face of the tower.

content.description: A wide crack leads to a ledge over a large chimney. Step over the void, take a hand crack up the slab to the saddle, and sling the mini-spire for a belay. A large, cuboidal crystal broke, and I fell into the chimney out of sight of the belayer. Trusting the crystals on the slab again led to the name. We used an arborist trick to rappel the summit and be able to pull the sling off.
content.location: This is left of the overhung piton crack on the northwest face of the route. It is possible to start in the cave/chimney.

content.description: Crawling on All 4s has great jams and gets a little wider as you go. Exit after the crack through the small crawl space under the leaning rock.
content.protection: Make sure to bring a #4 for the wider section.
content.location: Head downhill from the main bouldering area (toward the northeast), and you will locate a large jumble of rocks about halfway down.
